summary: The study investigates the impact of drug-polymer interactions on the release kinetics of PLGA and PLA/PEG nanoparticles (NPs) for controlled drug delivery. Key findings highlight that CURC-loaded PLGA NPs exhibit slower release rates and higher encapsulation efficiency, making them suitable for controlled delivery in regenerative medicine.
methods: Microfluidic-based synthesis was used to prepare nano-sized carriers (PLGA NPs and PLA/PEG micelles) loaded with hydrophobic drug curcumin (CURC). The NPs were characterized for physical properties, drug loading, and release kinetics, with cytotoxicity and antimicrobial activity evaluated.
results: NPs showed uniform size distribution (PDI ≤0.2) with Dₕ of 61.91 ± 1.86 nm for PLGA and 13.74 ± 0.97 nm for PLA/PEG. CURC-loaded PLGA NPs had higher encapsulation efficiency (EE%) and slower release rates compared to PLA/PEG micelles. No significant cytotoxicity was observed on NHDFs.
